methods.name: Radial Velocity
methods.description: Measures stellar wobble caused by orbiting planet's gravity. The star moves toward and away from us, shifting its light via the Doppler effect.

sensitivity.notes: Sensitivity degrades with period; requires quiet stars

biases: Favors short periods (more observations per orbit)
Activity from star spots can mimic signals

milestones.event: 51 Pegasi b - first planet around main-sequence star

methods.name: Transit (Kepler/K2)
methods.description: Detects planets crossing in front of their star, causing a small dip in brightness. Kepler mission revolutionized the field with continuous monitoring.

sensitivity.notes: Requires edge-on orbital alignment; measures radius, not mass

biases: Requires geometric alignment (rare for long periods)
Measures radius directly, mass requires follow-up
Small planets around large stars very hard to detect

methods.name: Transit (Ground/TESS)
methods.description: Ground-based surveys and TESS continue finding transiting planets, especially around bright nearby stars.

sensitivity.notes: Ground-based limited by atmosphere; TESS optimized for bright stars

biases: TESS: short observation baseline limits long periods
Favors planets around bright, nearby stars

methods.name: Gravitational Microlensing
methods.description: Uses gravity of a foreground star+planet system to magnify light from a background star. Planet causes a brief, detectable blip.

sensitivity.notes: Uniquely sensitive to cold planets at 1-10 AU including free-floating planets

biases: Best sensitivity at snow line (~3 AU)
Low detection rate requires monitoring millions of stars

milestones.event: Suzuki et al. mass-ratio function from MOA survey

methods.name: Direct Imaging
methods.description: Photographs planets directly by blocking starlight with coronagraphs or special optics. Currently limited to young, massive, widely-separated planets.

sensitivity.notes: Requires young systems where planets are still glowing from formation heat

biases: Only young planets (<100 Myr) are bright enough

milestones.event: HR 8799 system - first multi-planet direct image
First spectrum of directly imaged exoplanet

methods.name: Astrometry
methods.description: Measures the tiny wobble of a star's position on the sky caused by orbiting planets. Gaia is revolutionizing this technique.

sensitivity.notes: Requires exquisite positional precision; Gaia expected to find thousands

biases: Favors massive planets on wide orbits
Can determine true masses and 3D orbits

milestones.event: Gaia DR3 reveals first astrometric exoplanets
